title: Password Manager Does Not Work Properly on Wix
content:
The way the FF browser saves the password only links to the basic URL, users.wix.com. The problem being, it only offers the password options if one the sign up users page, which that URL default to. It will show the drop down menu with your login options. Once selecting login, FF no longer offers any password options, even with a right-click. Wix has a two page login, one with email, then the next with the password. It is like FF does not even recognize that first page properly. Only after manually entering the email, does the password just appear on the second page (if saved).

This is really sloppy functionality. It really stinks if it has been awhile since logging in, and you cannot remember what email was used with the account if several are related. It requires then manually going into setting and looking it up in the passwords section. I have never experienced this problem with other browsers.

It is there any way to get it to work normally with Wix (and possibly other similar two-step logins)?
creator: JJ80

title: Firefox tar.gz installation
content:
I installed firefox v130 from the tar.gz file to /opt. I use the latest enlightenment desktop on debian trixie. Firefox works great, I have no problems with it's functionality.

Unfortunately, I don't like the fact that it uses it's own window manager. When I install firefox from the debian repos (firefox-esr/testing,now 115.15.0esr-1) it uses the default window manager (enlightenment in this case). How can I get firefox to use the desktop window manager?

TIA
creator: gary216

title: Font symbols showing as text
content:
In my case in Google Calendar (I have seen similar questions about other apps)

Where there should be Symbols they show as text (see attached captures) Often running into and covering other text or boxes

I have tried: 1) Running Firefox in troubleshooting Mode (with no extensions etc) 2) Settings-General-Fonts-Advanced- Allow pages to choose own fonts 

   Changing this setting both Off and On and restarting Firefox (it was on originally)
creator: togolf80

title: Video content jiggles about on crunchyroll.com
content:
Hi all,

I have jumped ship from Chrome to Firefox today but I have encountered an issue with the site crunchyroll.com where the video content will jiggle around during playback (both full-screen and regular page view.) I have tested Youtube as well and the issue is not present on those videos. To give you a better picture of what it is like, it is like watching a video on an OLED screen with pixel shift enabled but it's super aggresive and is incredibly distracting.

To my memory I am pretty confident that the video player used on Crunyroll's website is a HTML5 player with DRM security and videos are in mp4 format.

I am running Firefox 131.0 (64-bit) completly fresh on Windows 11 with an RTX 30 series GPU. So far I have tried the following with no success and the jiggle remaining:

  1. Cleared the site data and cache
  2. Disabled Add-ons one-by-one to identify a potential culprit
  3. Disabled Hardware acceleration
  4. Ran Firefox in Safe Mode
  5. All of the above in combination

I am stumped as to why this might be happening especially with a fresh out-of-box experiance. Any assistance you can provide on this would be greatly appreciated, as I would prefer to avoid Chromium browsers going forward.

Many thanks, Phreaky
creator: Phreaky

title: Mozilla Firefox since v127.0 cannot install anymore the Adobe Acrobat Pro extension (adobe_acrobat-1.0-windows.xpi)
content:
Since Mozilla Firefox web browser v127.0 (released June 11 2024) the manual installation of the Adobe Acrobat Pro extension (the adobe_acrobat-1.0-windows.xpi file) do not work anymore!  :disappointed_face:

So, when you go in any higher version of Mozilla Firefox web browser then v126.0.1 (released May 28, 2024) to this web browser Menu Bar -> Tools -> Add-ons and Themes -> Extensions -> Install Add-on From File..., and then try to manually import-install the Adobe Acrobat Pro extension (the adobe_acrobat-1.0-windows.xpi file) into the Mozilla Firefox web browser, and from this HDD location:

C:\Program Files (x86)\Adobe\Acrobat DC\Acrobat\Browser\WCFirefoxExtn\WebExtn\signed_extn\adobe_acrobat-1.0-windows.xpi

The Mozilla Firefox web browser will say during this .xpi file installation: "This add on could not be installed because it appears to be corrupt"!  :disappointed_face:

However, in any Mozilla Firefox web browser version prior v127.0 (released June 11 2024), this manual import-installation of the adobe_acrobat-1.0-windows.xpi file will be most successfully installed in a Mozilla Firefox web browser without any problem!

I also create the most detailed and step-by-step post on the Mozillazine.org Forum and the Adobe Forum about all of this problem:

https://community.adobe.com/t5/acrobat-discussions/mozilla-firefox-since-v127-0-cannot-install-anymore-the-adobe-acrobat-pro-xpi-extension/m-p/14893786#M480889


So, please help and advice further. Thank you in advance and best regards!
creator: Brus
